bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Maria Teresa Rojas and Lydia Cabrera, February 21, 1952

div1.p: The Hench's enjoyed their visit with Rojas and Cabrera. Hench is meeting with Rath and Grant of the National Trust next week, and will show them pictures of the San Jose property.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Maria Teresa Rojas and Lydia Cabrera, February 21, 1952
div1.opener:
February 21, 1952
Senora Maria Teresa Rojas
Senorita Lydia Cabrera
Finca San Jose
Calzada Real y Gomez Redencion
Quemados de Marianao
Havana, Cuba
Dear Maria and Lydia:
div1.p:
We were sorry not to be able to say goodbye to you at the boat but we fully
understood and know how vexatious it was for you to have been held up so long,
two days in fact, doing the job that you were trying to finish. As the boat
left the harbor, Mary and I saw a car and two women waved to us. We thought
it might be you and vigorously waved back but we were not sure.

I cannot tell you how much we appreciated all the kindness, hospitality
and generosity which you bestowed in such full measures upon us. You are
delightful hostesses friends and I do hope our paths cross often. I wouldn't
wish for you to be here in Rochester as it is very cold with much snow
today but I do hope that you can visit here non-professionally sometime.

On the train coming home I developed a severe cold from which I am just
recovering. I leave today for Washington. I have a date to see General
Grant and Mr. Rath next Monday. I am taking with me some pictures of the
Finca San Jose which I took myself and I will let you know on my return all
that I learn.

Would you kindly send to Mary the name and address of “Fifi” Tarafa. We came
off without her address and do not know her real first name. In Havana I
purchased a Cuban telephone book for just such purposes but could not find it
listed, nor could I find listed the address of Mr. and Mrs. Aosborne Hill.
Incidentally, I am afraid that Mary and I made several faux pas. When we were
first introduced to him I thought his name was a hyphenated English name -
Aosborne-Hill and I am sure that on several occasions Mary and I called
them Mr. and Mrs. Aosborne. Apparently I am wrong and Aosborne is his first
name. Is that correct? I should like to drop him a note.

I do hope that Mr. Massaguer will be good enough to send Mary the cartoon
which he made of her. If you do not hear from him would you kindly send
me his address. I don't know that he would answer a request of mine any more
than one from you but I can try.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
